review.title: On the Solvability of Inductive Problems: A Study in Epistemic Topology
review.abstract: We investigate the issues of inductive problem-solving and learning by doxastic agents. We provide topological characterizations of solvability and learnability, and we use them to prove that AGM-style belief revision is "universal", i.e., that every solvable problem is solvable by AGM conditioning.

sections.heading: 7 Conclusions and Connections to Other Work
sections.text: The general topological attitude to problem-solving is here a variation of the concept advocated by Kelly in various conversations [23] and in unpublished papers [24, 25], although until recently we have not recognized this close similarity. Our topological characteristics of testable, falsifiable properties are generalizations of Kelly's results [20], which demonstrate characteristics for the specific case of Baire spaces. Our result in the field of learning universality (Corollar3) is also a generalization of Kelly's analog results [21, 26], and it is a generalization in the field of Baire spaces. But our generalization is highly non-trivial, which requires the use of T-universality.

sections.heading: 8 Acknowledgments
sections.text: We thank Johan van Benthem, Nick Bezhanishvili, Konstantin Genin, Thomas Icard and Kevin Kelly for their useful feedback on issues related to this work. Johan helped us place faith-based learning in the broader context of long-term doxastic protocols [7], and furthermore gave us his continued support and encouragement for our work on this line of research. Nick pointed out the connections between our work and the notions of TD space and locally coherent frameworks. Konstantin pointed out the connections with the concept of layering and provided the counterexample to the evidence of Proposition 5. His critical feedback on our early drafts was really important in clarifying our thoughts and cleaning up our evidence, so it is fair to say that this paper in its current form owes much to Konstantin Genin. Thomas Icard's comments on an earlier draft and our friendly interactions with him on related topics during our visits to Stanford are greatly appreciated.
